formalpara.title: Image Formats - raw vs. QCOW2
formalpara.para: As previously mentioned, Glance supports a variety of image formats; however raw and QCOW2 are the most common. While QCOW2 does provide some benefits (supports copy-on-write, snapshots, dynamic expansion) over the raw format, it should be noted that when images are copied into Cinder volumes, they are converted into the raw format once stored on a NetApp backend.

note.para: Use of the QCOW2 image format is recommended for ephemeral disks due to its inherent benefits when taking instance snapshots. Use of the raw image format can be advantageous when using Cinder volumes as persistent boot disks as a conversion from an alternate format to raw that would be performed by Cinder can be avoided. Both raw and QCOW2 formats respond well to NetApp's deduplication technology which is often utilized with Glance deployments.

formalpara.title: NFS with Deduplication
formalpara.para:
Since there is a high probability of duplicate blocks in a repository of virtual machine images, it is highly recommended to enable deduplication on the FlexVol volume(s) where the images are stored. You can check the status of deduplication for a particular FlexVol volume by using the volume efficiency show command as seen below. ::> volume efficiency show -vserver demo-vserver -volume vol2

simplesect.title: Enhanced Instance Creation
simplesect.para:
NetApp contributed a capability to enhance instance creation which focuses on booting tenant-requested VM instances by OpenStack Compute Service (Nova) using disk images in the shortest possible time and in the most storage capacity efficient manner possible. This Enhanced Persistent Instance Creation feature (sometimes referred to as Rapid Cloning) is achieved by:
Copying the disk image from Glance to a Cinder volume whose backend leverages the NetApp NFS drivers (in either clustered Data ONTAP or Data ONTAP operating in 7-Mode) for the first boot request for a particular image The copied image is cached in the storage backend using unutilized available storage Upon subsequent requests to boot instances from this image on the same backend, an efficient controller-side clone is performed from the cache rather than re-downloading the image from Glance.

Additionally, if the Glance image repository is using a file storage backend served by an NFS mount from the same NetApp FlexVol volume as the Cinder data store, then we are able to avoid the initial copy described in Step 1 above and perform an efficient controller-side copy which completes nearly instantaneously. Note that the show_image_direct_url configuration parameter must be to True in the Glance configuration file glance-api.conf. This ensures that the appropriate metadata will be passed to Cinder so that it can attempt to rapidly clone the image directly on the controller, avoiding the HTTP transfer between Glance and Cinder.
This strategy can significantly decrease the time elapsed when the Nova service is fulfilling image provisioning and boot requests.

Leveraging the “boot from image (creates a new volume)” option in Nova, you can leverage the enhanced instance creation capabilities described above. Normally volumes created as a result of this option are persistent beyond the life of the instance. However, you can select the “delete on terminate” option in combination with the “boot from image (creates a new volume)” option to create an ephemeral volume while still leveraging the enhanced instance creation capabilities described above. This can provide a significantly faster provisioning and boot sequence than the normal way that ephemeral disks are provisioned, where a copy of the disk image is made from Glance to local storage on the hypervisor node where the instance will reside.

There are three tunable parameters within the Cinder driver configuration that can affect the behavior of how often space utilized by the NFS image cache managed by the NetApp unified driver is reclaimed for other uses: namely, thres_avl_size_perc_start, thres_avl_size_perc_stop, and expiry_thres_minutes. For more information on these parameters, refer to .
